title: Pro-Trump Silicon Valley Hopeful About the Future
content:
People take to the streets of San Francisco to protest Donald Trump ’ s win . Photo by Misyrlena Egkolfopoulou
The night that Donald Trump won the presidential election , technology executive John Gable was having dinner with his family . Ordinarily , Gable would host a party at his house with finger foods and drinks on election night , an event that he liked to refer to as “ The Superbowl of politics. ” But this year the family stayed in . Gable was too nervous about the results to socialize .
Midway through his meal , he was unable to keep still any longer . Gable excused himself and rushed to the living room to check the results . He nervously flipped between MSNBC and Fox News . Still chewing on his rosemary beef stew , he heard polling database FiftyThiryEight give Trump a 78 percent chance of winning . Gable felt relieved .
“ I was convinced that things were going to be the same or a little worse with Clinton and under Trump I could see they could be better , ” the 51-year old said . “ He is going to change things . ”
In the weeks since Donald Trump won the presidential election , the tech industry has been grappling with shock , anger , and uncertainty . In recent years , Silicon Valley has enjoyed a particularly close relationship with President Barack Obama , who visited the Valley many times , invited tech executives to the White House and even created the U.S. Chief Technology Officer role , the first ever tech job for the government .
But the industry ’ s relationship with Trump has been rockier . Trump threatened to boycott Apple when the tech giant didn ’ t follow an F.B.I . order earlier this year to unlock the San Bernardino shooter ’ s iPhone . He attacked Amazon CEO and Washington Post owner Jeff Bezos , accusing him of using the newspaper as a tax dodge . He also accused Google of hiding negative news about Hillary Clinton in its search engine .
While Silicon Valley has its libertarian Republican supporters , Trump ’ s racist , sexist and controversial comments pushed many of them to Hillary Clinton ’ s side . In July , more than 140 tech industry leaders , executives , analysts and experts signed a letter outlining the reasons why a Trump presidency would be “ a disaster for innovation. ” According to Crowdpac , a nonpartisan group that tracks campaign donations , tech employees and executives gave a total of $ 8.1 million to candidates . Of that , 95 percent , or $ 7.7 million , went to Hillary Clinton ’ s campaign . Donald Trump received about $ 300,000 dollars , or 4 percent , and Libertarian nominee Gary Johnson received less than 1 percent .
Silicon Valley has good reason to be afraid of how a Trump presidency will impact them given the fraught exchanges during the campaign . But some like Gable are looking forward to the new regime . They believe that Trump ’ s outsider status will challenge the traditional establishment in Washington .
In the months leading up to the election , Peter Thiel , the billionaire venture capitalist and Facebook board member , travelled the country to convince voters to look past Donald Trump ’ s flaws and vote for him in order to challenge the establishment and break Washington ’ s status quo .
“ We ’ re voting for Trump because we judge the leadership of our country to have failed , ” Thiel said in a press conference at the National Press Club .
“ Donald Trump scares Democrats and Republicans , ” said the CEO of All Sides , a website that collects and compares headlines from the left , right and center to create a discussion around different perspectives . “ He is more likely to make a more radical change in Washington D.C. than anyone else . ”
Gable said he also believes that Trump will come up with economic policies that are favorable to the tech industry .
“ I always thought of him as the art of the deal , because he is comfortable making deals , ” said Gable . “ I like some of his economic ideas . Others I don ’ t . But I do think that things are going to be different . ”
So far , the president-elect has said he wants to de-regulate the market and has vowed to dismantle the Dodd-Frank Act , a financial regulation plan that was put in place following the 2008 economic collapse .
Trump supporters in the technology industry are also excited about his plan to lower corporate taxes , which could boost earnings .
“ That ’ s the only thing that Silicon Valley possibly likes , ” said Tim Bajarin , president of Creative Strategies , a market research firm in Silicon Valley .
Wall Street also appears to be buoyed by the prospect of Trump ’ s market friendly policy proposals . The Dow increased by nearly 600 points in the three days after Trump ’ s victory . Stocks of financial companies in the S & P 500 jumped about 11 percent in the week after the election .
To be certain , not all of Trump ’ s economic policy agenda would be helpful to the industry . He has threatened to impose tariffs on foreign products entering the U.S. , and he opposes the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement , a trade deal involving 11 countries in the Pacific region . Trump has argued that the agreement could hurt American workers and undermine U.S. companies , but critics worry about triggering a trade war .
“ It could force retaliation from the other countries to then put tariffs on U.S. goods going into their countries , ” Bajarin said .
Trump also plans to impose tariffs on companies that move production overseas . His critics believe this could hurt companies like Apple or Intel , which manufacture their products in countries with cheaper labor , like China .
But one Google employee , who declined to be named and identifies as a conservative , said he agreed with Trump ’ s policy .
“ I think that it ’ s good that he wants companies to produce more consumer goods in the United States , ” he said , adding that it could actually help improve the companies ’ brand image .
Much has been made by Trump ’ s extreme comments during the campaign . In his speeches , he threatened to deport immigrants , ban Muslims from entering the country , and planned on building a wall in the border with Mexico . But Trump ’ s Silicon Valley supporters said that the comments weren ’ t meant to be taken literally . Rather they should be seen as proof that he was ready to tackle some of the country ’ s biggest problems head-on .
“ Let ’ s be honest , a few years ago Trump was a Democrat . He is not Ted Cruz . He is not some hardcore religious conservative , ” the aforementioned Google employee said . “ For the first time in a long time the Valley should be able to feel like they can talk to a Republican administration sort of on equal footing . ”
As Silicon Valley prepares for the unanticipated political reality , tech executives are hoping that ’ s true . They are trying to find ways to connect with the new administration . Apple CEO Tim Cook and Microsoft founder Bill Gates called Donald Trump after the election and congratulated him on his win . Google announced a job posting for a manager of “ conservative outreach. ” Trump has responded by inviting leaders from some of the biggest tech companies to New York for a round-table discussion , according to The New York Times .
In the meantime , Trump supporters say they hope that the election will puncture the Silicon Valley ’ s cultural bubble and will help bridge the disconnect with the rest of America . They hope that the election result could be the wake-up call that Silicon Valley needed to understand the changing reality in the U.S .
“ There ’ s a real question of ignorance on our part , ” said Richard Walker , professor emeritus of geography at University of California , Berkeley , who focuses on economic and political trends in the state . “ People in the Bay Area have no idea what life is like for a lot of people , how long that ’ s been the case and they haven ’ t been concerned about that . ”
Republicans say they hope that those attitude changes will also bring an acceptance of their beliefs . They hope they might one day be able to come out of hiding .
“ I found Mississippi in the 80 ’ s to be more open to different political views than I find San Francisco and Silicon Valley today , ” Gable said , adding that he hopes his website All Sides will help the technology industry have a more open , accepting conversation around politics .
“ Thomas Jefferson said it is healthy to have a mini-revolution every once in a while , ” Gable said . “ Andrew Jackson was a mini-revolution . Teddy Roosevelt was a mini-revolution . Ronald Reagan was a mini-revolution . Donald Trump is a mini-revolution . ”
